Hypothesis Tests for Identifying Outlying Providers

Source: R/test_fe.R
test_fe.Rd

Hypothesis Tests for Identifying Outlying Providers

test_fe(
  fit,
  parm,
  level = 0.95,
  test = "exact.poisbinom",
  null = "median",
  n = 10000
)

Arguments

fit

an object as output of logis_fe function.

parm

specify a subset of which providers are to be given confidence intervals. All providers are included by default.

level

confidence level used for constructing confidence intervals. Defaulting to 0.95.

test

a character string specifying the type of testing method to be conducted. Defaulting to "exact.poisbinom".

  • "exact.poisbinom": two-sided exact test based on Poisson-binomial distribution of \(O_i|Z_i\)

  • "exact.bootstrap": two-sided exact test based on bootstrap procedure

  • "wald": wald test

  • "score": score test

null

a character string or real number specifying null hypotheses of fixed provider effects.

n

resample size for bootstrapping. Defaulting to 10,000.

...

Value

a dataframe containing:

flag

a vector of flagging indicator. "1" means better, and "-1" means worse

p

p-value

stat

z-score

Details

By default, the function uses the "exact.poisbinom" method. The wald test is invalid for extreme providers (i.e. when provider effect goes to infinity).

References

  • Wu, W, Yang, Y, Kang, J, He, K. (2022) Improving large-scale estimation and inference for profiling health care providers. Statistics in Medicine, 41(15): 2840-2853.

Examples

data(data_FE)
data.prep <- fe_data_prep(data_FE$Y, data_FE$Z, data_FE$ID, message = FALSE)
fit_fe <- logis_fe(data.prep)
test_fe(fit_fe)
#>    flag            p       stat
#> 1     0 6.624388e-01 -0.4365486
#> 2     0 1.965498e-01  1.2914439
#> 3    -1 1.264412e-03 -3.2239370
#> 4     1 1.547222e-05  4.3218560
#> 5     0 7.992864e-01  0.2542707
#> 6     0 2.577034e-01 -1.1318361
#> 7     0 7.828967e-01 -0.2755461
#> 8     0 7.678697e-01  0.2951626
#> 9     1 3.317876e-03  2.9366413
#> 10    0 7.044033e-01 -0.3793832
